---
title: 'Dilemmas in recovery-oriented practice to support people with co-occurring
  mental health and substance use disorders: A qualitative study of staff experiences
  in Norway'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-34QTHXE2" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Brekke, E., Lien, L., Nysveen, K., &#38; Biong, S. (2018). Dilemmas in recovery-oriented practice to support people with co-occurring mental health and substance use disorders: A qualitative study of staff experiences in Norway. <i>International Journal of Mental Health Systems</i>, <i>12</i>(30). <a href="https://doi.org/10.1186/s13033-018-0211-5">https://doi.org/10.1186/s13033-018-0211-5</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-34QTHXE2" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-34QTHXE2" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Brekke et al. gjennomførte ein studie for å forstå utfordringane tilsette står overfor i recovery-orienterte tenester for personar med både mentale helseproblem og ruslidingar. Dei intervjua praktikarar i Noreg over to år og identifiserte tre hovuddilemma: å balansere mellom å hjelpe klientar til å føle seg styrka og å anerkjenne deira utfordringar, å vere retningsgivande samtidig som ein opprettheld ein ikkje-dømmande haldning, og å handtere spenninga mellom å fremje total avholdenhet og å akseptere noko rusbruk. Desse funna framhevar kompleksiteten i å tilby effektiv støtte og antyder at nye strategiar er nødvendige for å takle desse problema. Denne forskinga er viktig fordi ho kan bidra til å forbetre måten tenester blir levert til personar med samtidige lidingar, og gjere recovery meir oppnåeleg og berekraftig.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-34QTHXE2" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Recovery-orientert praksis, Samtidige lidingar, Mental helse, Rusbruk, Tilsette sine erfaringar, Dilemma
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-34QTHXE2" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    Background 
Recovery-oriented practice is recommended in services for people with co-occurring mental health and substance use disorders. Understanding practitioners’ perceptions of recovery-oriented services may be a key component of implementing recovery principles in day-to-day practice. This study explores and describes staff experiences with dilemmas in recovery-oriented practice to support people with co-occurring disorders. 
 
Methods 
Three focus group interviews were carried out over the course of 2 years with practitioners in a Norwegian community mental health and addictions team that was committed to developing recovery-oriented services. Thematic analysis was applied to yield descriptions of staff experiences with dilemmas in recovery-oriented practice. 
 
Results 
Three dilemmas were described: (1) balancing mastery and helplessness, (2) balancing directiveness and a non-judgmental attitude, and (3) balancing total abstinence and the acceptance of substance use. 
 
Conclusions 
Innovative approaches to practice development that address the inherent dilemmas in recovery-oriented practice to support people with co-occurring disorders are called for
  </article>
